Panel B shows the XRD patterns of FeCoK/ZrO2 following calcination at 400 °C for 4 h (a), reduction at 400 °C for 5 h (b), reaction at 360 °C for 12 h (c) and KNO3/ZrO2 (d). The primary aim of this study is to understand the role of ZrO2 in iron-cobalt-potassium (FeCoK) based catalysts for converting syngas to light olefins. Our findings reveal that ZrO2 support notably enhances the dispersion of Fe, Co, and K species, thus improving the reducibility of Fe2O3, Co3O4, and KNO3. This leads to increased medium and strong hydrogen adsorption and elevated medium basicity. At lower temperatures (300 °C and 320 °C), the space-time yield (STY) of hydrocarbons over FeCoK/ZrO2 is less than FeCoK due to the strong adsorption of intermediates by the increased basicity. However, at higher temperatures (360 °C and 380 °C), this trend reverses, indicating the high-temperature mitigates strong adsorption effects. The FeCoK/ZrO2 catalyst achieved the best STY of C2 C4 olefins of 13.2 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 380 °C. Introduction In the realm of petrochemical synthesis, light olefins like ethylene, propylene, and butylene play a pivotal role as precursors for a myriad of chemicals, ranging from polymers to pharmaceuticals and solvents [1]. Traditionally, the production of these olefins has been achieved through methods such as thermal cracking in the presence of steam, utilizing hydrocarbons derived from petroleum or the liquid components of natural gas [2–4], which, while effective, face challenges including environmental concerns and the volatility of fossil fuel reserves. This situation necessitates the exploration of alternative, more sustainable pathways for olefin production. Synthesis gas, commonly referred to as syngas and composed of CO and H2 sourced from renewable resources, is emerging as a promising alternative feedstock, presenting a more sustainable and cost-effective option. [4,5]. Within the realm of Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis, syngas is converted into hydrocarbons using catalysts based on iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co), with each catalyst type exhibiting a unique selectivity for products attributable to their differing electronic and chemical characteristics [6–12]. Typically active at temperatures ranging from 250 to 350 °C, Fe-based catalysts are predisposed to splitting CO, which results in the generation of iron carbide on the catalyst's surface, thus skewing the production towards olefin-rich compounds [12–15]. On the other hand, Co-based catalysts, which are operative at comparatively lower temperatures (200–250 °C), are more inclined to yield paraffinic compounds, given their less pronounced ability to dissociate CO [11,16]. Modifying these catalysts with alkali metals such as Na and K has been shown to modulate their activity, particularly enhancing the output of lighter olefins [7,17–21]. Previous studies highlight the crucial role of Fe species in product distribution, with FexC phases leading to hydrocarbon formation, including light olefins, while metallic Fe and FexOy promote methane and CO2 formation, respectively [13,14]. Research comparing various supports for Fe-K catalysts, such as SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, and carbon materials, has identified ZrO2 as particularly effective in enhancing light olefin selectivity and yield [22,23]. This observation was ascribed to a surface enriched with carbon and a more ordered arrangement of carbon entities throughout the reaction [23]. Additionally, interactions between Fe and Zr species have been found to reduce their crystallite sizes, inhibit Fe sintering, enhance catalyst stability, prevent θ-Fe3C and coke deposition, and suppress light paraffin formation, thereby increasing light olefin selectivity and the olefin/paraffin ratio [24–27]. Moreover, Ding et al. [28] discovered that addition of Zr created more oxygen vacancies in FeCoK-based catalysts, leading to a surface rich in hydroxyl groups and a higher ethylene formation rate. However, Lohitharn et al. [29,30] reported that Zr addition to FeCuSiO2 catalysts increased activity for both the conversion of CO with hydrogen and the water-gas shift reaction without affecting Fe reducibility and hydrocarbon selectivity. Building on these diverse findings, our study seeks to further clarify the role of Zr promoters in catalyst performance, especially in light olefin formation during syngas conversion. We explore the impact of ZrO2 on FeCoK catalyst performance, which presents an opportunity to challenge and expand upon the existing assumptions in the syngas-to-light olefins (STO) conversion process. Through comprehensive characterization of the ZrO2-promoted FeCoK catalyst, we aim to understand the structure-activity relationship for STO in comparison to the unsupported FeCoK. Experimental Preparation of ZrO2 support The ZrO2 support was synthesized through a precipitation process, starting with a solution of ZrOCl2·8H2O (12.9 g dissolved in 100 mL deionized water). Following the methodology reported by Du et al. [31], ammonia hydroxide was added to the solution to adjust its pH to 9. This mixture was then stirred continuously at room temperature for 6 h. After stirring, the resulting slurry was filtered and thoroughly washed with deionized water to remove any chloride ions. The final step involved drying the filtered product at 110 °C overnight, followed by calcination at 400 °C for 2 h in an air atmosphere. Preparation of FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts A FeCoK catalyst was synthesized by dissolving 0.168 g of KNO3, 0.897 g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, and 0.128 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O in 6 mL of deionized (DI) water to achieve the target atomic ratio of Fe:Co:K = 1:0.2:0.75. The mixture was agitated at 60 °C for 4 h, dried at 100 °C for 12 h, and then calcined at 400 °C for 4 h. In parallel, a FeCoK/ZrO2 catalyst was prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation technique in a two-step process. Initially, 1.0 g of ZrO2 was mixed with an aqueous solution of 0.168 g of KNO3. This mixture was agitated at 60 °C for 4 h and then dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The resulting K-incorporated ZrO2 was then further impregnated with a solution containing the prescribed amounts of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.897 g) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.128 g), maintaining the same atomic ratio of Fe:Co:K as in the FeCoK catalyst. The impregnated sample underwent identical drying and calcination conditions as those used for the FeCoK catalyst preparation. For a detailed account of the catalyst characterization methods and the protocol for testing catalytic activity, please refer to the supplementary material. Results and discussion Characterization of FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts Fig. 1 illustrates the adsorption isotherms for FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts. The FeCoK isotherm exhibits characteristics of a type II isotherm, indicative of non-porous materials, as evidenced by a plateau of N2 sorption along with the relative pressures. In contrast, the FeCoK/ZrO2 isotherm aligns with a type IV isotherm and displays an H3 hysteresis loop, characteristic of mesoporous materials formed by non-rigid particle aggregates. The FeCoK/ZrO2 catalyst demonstrates a significantly higher total nitrogen adsorption volume, suggesting a larger pore volume compared to the FeCoK catalyst. The pore size distribution of FeCoK appears quite flat, reinforcing the non-porous nature aligned with the observed type II isotherm. Conversely, the FeCoK/ZrO2 pore size distribution reveals a notable peak at approximately 4.2 nm, falling within the mesoporous range. Additionally, a broader pore size distribution within 10–100 nm was observed for FeCoK/ZrO2, implying the presence of particles varying in size. The BET surface area and total pore volume measurements for FeCoK are markedly lower at 1.2 m²/g and 0.004 cm³/g, respectively. In comparison, FeCoK/ZrO2 exhibits significantly higher values of 18.9 m²/g and 0.04 cm³/g, respectively, underscoring the enhanced porosity and potential catalytic activity of the FeCoK/ZrO2 catalyst. Fig. 2 A and B display XRD patterns of FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 following various treatments: calcination at 400 °C for 4 h (a), reduction at 400 °C for 5 h (b), and reaction at 360 °C for 12 h (c). The XRD pattern of calcined FeCoK (Fig. 2Aa) exhibits diffraction peaks corresponding to Fe2O3 (PDF 01–071–5088), Co3O4 (PDF 01–073–1701), and orthorhombic KNO3 (PDF 01–005–0377). Conversely, the calcined FeCoK/ZrO2 (Fig. 2Ba) predominantly shows orthorhombic KNO3 (PDF 01–005–0377), monoclinic ZrO2 (PDF 00–037–1484), and tetragonal ZrO2 (PDF 00–065–0729) phases, but lacks distinct diffraction lines for Fe and Co species. This absence could be attributed to the small crystallite sizes of these species and the potential overlapping of their diffraction lines with ZrO2 phases. To further elucidate the structures of the FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts, TEM analysis was conducted. As depicted in Fig. 3 , TEM images of calcined FeCoK at low magnification (Fig. 3a) reveal an amalgamation of small particles, approximately 10–20 nm in size, alongside larger crystals ranging from 35 to 100 nm which are likely Fe2O3 and Co3O4, respectively, inferred from the dimensions of their lattice fringes (Fig. 3b). In contrast, the low-magnification TEM image of FeCoK/ZrO2 (Fig. 3c) reveals aggregates of particles, which contribute to the formation of porosity as supported by the N2-sorption analysis (Fig. 1). These aggregates are composed of Fe2O3, Co3O4, KNO3, and ZrO2 particles (Fig. 3d) and lack the distinctive, larger Co3O4 crystal structures seen in the FeCoK sample (Fig. 3a and b). The TEM images suggest that the incorporation of Fe, Co, and K species onto a ZrO2 support enhances their dispersion. The reduction behavior of Fe2O3, Co3O4, and KNO3 in the calcined FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts was examined through H2-TPR analysis. For comparative purposes, the H2-TPR profiles of Fe2O3/KNO3, KNO3/ZrO2, pure KNO3, and Fe2O3 Co3O4 mixed oxide were also included. As depicted in Fig. 4 , the mixed oxide Fe2O3 Co3O4 exhibits reduction peaks at approximately 265, 317, 378, and 593 °C. These peaks are indicative of the stepwise reduction from Co3O4 to CoO and then to metallic Co, as well as the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, followed by its transition to metallic Fe. Pure KNO3 shows a notable peak at 703 °C, likely corresponding to its thermal decomposition and reduction. When KNO3 is impregnated on ZrO2, the reduction profile shifts to a lower temperature peak at 489 °C, suggesting that the ZrO2 support may influence the decomposition of KNO3, possibly due to enhanced KNO3 particle dispersion or facilitation of KNO3 reduction by hydrogen spillover from ZrO2. The Fe2O3-KNO3 sample exhibits a shoulder at 400 °C, which may be attributed to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Subsequently, a pronounced reduction peak at 506 °C is observed, suggesting further reduction of Fe3O4 to metallic Fe, along with reduction or decomposition of KNO3. A peak at 580 °C corresponds to the reduction temperature of Fe3O4 to metallic Fe observed in the Fe2O3 Co3O4 profile. Additionally, a broad peak at 913 °C may denote the reduction of a strong interaction between oxidic Fe and K species. For the FeCoK sample, the H2-TPR profiles are similar to those of the Fe2O3-KNO3 sample, but with a shift toward lower temperatures, which implies that Co presence facilitates the reduction of mixed metal oxides. The FeCoK/ZrO2 profile commences reduction around 220 °C, likely due to the onset of Co3O4 reduction. A subsequent shoulder at 299 °C may be related to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. The peak at 333 °C suggests the concurrent reduction of Fe3O4 to metallic Fe and KNO3, while the peak at 423 °C is possibly due to the reduction of remaining Fe3O4 to metallic Fe. The extended peak at 512 °C might signify interactions between Co and Fe species with ZrO2 [32] or between Fe and K species. Overall, these results imply that Co, Fe, and K species undergo more facile reduction when dispersed on ZrO2 support, as demonstrated by the lower onset temperatures for reduction in the FeCoK/ZrO2 profile compared to FeCoK. The crystallographic phases of the FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts after a pre-reduction process conducted at 400 °C for 5 h were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), with the results depicted in Figs. 2Ab and 2Bb, respectively. The XRD spectrum of the pre-reduced FeCoK (seen in Fig. 2Ab) reveals the transformation of the initial Fe2O3, Co3O4, and KNO3 phases observed in the calcined catalyst into KCoO2 (PDF 00–029–0996), KFeO2 (PDF 01–078–9441), and elemental Fe (PDF 03–065–4899). The appearance of the KFeO2 phase aligns with the H2-TPR data, indicating a pronounced interaction between the Fe and K species upon reduction. Moreover, the pronounced diffraction line of metallic Fe, in contrast to the small diffraction lines of Fe2O3 (Fig. 2Aa), implies a coalescence of Fe particles during the reduction process. The results suggest that a portion of the Fe in FeCoK is in close contact with K, resulting in the formation of KFeO2, while the rest remains as isolated metallic Fe particles. On the other hand, the pre-reduced FeCoK/ZrO2 (Fig. 2Bb) displays prominent diffraction lines corresponding to elemental Fe (PDF 03–065–4899) and the monoclinic and tetragonal phases of ZrO2. The absence of distinct KCoO2 and KFeO2 phases could be attributed to either their low crystallinity or the overlap of their diffraction lines with those of the ZrO2 phases. Nevertheless, the TEM image of FeCoK/ZrO2 (Fig. 3d) reveals a close proximity between Fe2O3 and KNO3, which likely leads to the formation of KFeO2 during the reduction process. The adsorptive properties of hydrogen over FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 were analyzed using (H2-TPD) techniques, as shown in Fig. 5a. The H2-TPD profile of FeCoK was deconvoluted into peaks representing different adsorption strengths: weak (129 °C), medium (204 and 303 °C), and strong (445 °C). These peaks likely correspond to H2 interactions with metallic species, KCoO2, KFeO2, and potassium-rich oxides on the FeCoK surface. In contrast, the H2-TPD profile for FeCoK/ZrO2 revealed three distinct peaks, but with significantly larger desorption peaks at medium and strong adsorption sites compared to the unsupported FeCoK. The H2-TPD profile of pure ZrO2 exhibited a broad H2 desorption peak, indicating the capability of pure ZrO2 to adsorb H2 on its surface. The introduction of potassium onto the ZrO2 did not significantly alter the H2-TPD profile when compared to pure ZrO2. Quantitative details of hydrogen desorption for all samples are tabulated in Table 1 . The unsupported FeCoK showed the highest amount of weakly adsorbed H2 (7.8 µmol g−1), which is likely due to the prevalence of metallic phases. Pure ZrO2 had a total H2 adsorption of 23.34 µmol g−1, similar to that of the unsupported FeCoK, but with the largest fraction of strong H2 adsorption sites (54.6 %). With the addition of potassium, the ZrO2 displayed a decrease in strong H2 adsorption sites, coupled with an increase in medium-strength sites. Remarkably, the total amount of H2 desorbed from FeCoK/ZrO2 significantly increased to 73.37 µmol g−1, which is threefold that of the unsupported FeCoK and 3.89 times higher than that of K/ZrO2. This indicates a cooperative interaction between Fe and Co and the ZrO2 support, which enhances the availability of medium and strong hydrogen adsorption sites. The surface basicity of FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts was investigated using the CO2-TPD technique. The CO2-TPD profile of FeCoK reveals five distinct peaks at 64, 137, 224, 374, and 510 °C. The first peak observed at 64 °C is likely indicative of the physical adsorption of CO2. The subsequent peaks at 137 °C and 224 °C are attributed to weak CO2 adsorption, while the peaks at 374 °C and 510 °C are interpreted as representing medium and strong CO2 adsorption sites, respectively. In a similar vein, the CO2-TPD profile for FeCoK/ZrO2 is characterized by four peaks, occurring at 106, 170, 346, and 543 °C. These are assigned to weak (106 °C and 170 °C), medium (346 °C), and strong (543 °C) CO2 adsorption, respectively. The quantified amounts of CO2 adsorbed are detailed in Table 2 . Although the total CO2 adsorption capacities of FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 are comparable, at 54.5 µmol g−1 and 58.9 µmol g−1, there is a notable difference in the distribution of adsorption site strength. FeCoK is predominantly characterized by weak CO2 adsorption sites, which constitute 45.9 % of the total. In contrast, the incorporation of Fe, Co, and K species onto the ZrO2 support in FeCoK/ZrO2 significantly favors the formation of medium-strength CO2 adsorption sites, accounting for 64.9 % of the total adsorption. Comparion of catalytic performance for FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 Fig. 6a presents the CO conversion rates over FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts, demonstrating a general increase with rising reaction temperatures for both. At lower temperatures of 300 °C and 320 °C, FeCoK exhibits significantly higher CO conversion of 45.2 % and 81.1 %, respectively, compared to 25.6 % and 56.2 % for FeCoK/ZrO2. However, at 340 °C, the conversions of the two catalysts converge to a similar range of 84.2–86.0 %. Notably, beyond 340 °C, FeCoK/ZrO2 begins to outperform FeCoK, achieving a peak conversion rate of 94.0 % at 360 °C. The formation rates of CO2 and hydrocarbons, indicative of CO conversion, are depicted in Figs. 6b and 6c, respectively. FeCoK shows a volcanic trend in the formation rate of CO2 in terms of the space-time yield (STY), starting at 21.23 mmol gcat −1 h − 1 at 300 °C, peaking at 29.2 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 320 °C, and then diminishing to 22.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 380 °C. In contrast, the STY of CO2 for FeCoK/ZrO2 at 300 °C and 320 °C is significantly lower, at 11.3 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and 19.9 mmol gcat −1 h−1 respectively, but aligns closely with FeCoK at elevated temperatures of 360 °C and 380 °C. Regarding the hydrocarbons production, FeCoK/ZrO2 initially demonstrates lower space-time yields (STY) than FeCoK at 300 °C and 320 °C. However, its performance improves markedly at higher temperatures, surpassing FeCoK at 340 °C and reaching a peak STY of 36.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 380 °C, compared to 30 mmol gcat −1 h−1 for FeCoK. This suggests that at lower temperatures, FeCoK/ZrO2 may adsorb intermediates more strongly, leading to a reduced formation rate of CO2 and hydrocarbons. Nonetheless, the catalytic activity of FeCoK/ZrO2 improves at elevated temperatures. As inferred from the basicity analysis (CO2-TPD shown in Fig. 5b), the predominant medium basic sites on FeCoK/ZrO2 may account for the lower activity at reduced temperatures. However, as the temperature exceeds 340 °C, the interaction between intermediates and the FeCoK/ZrO2 surface may weaken, thus enhancing the production rates of CO2 and hydrocarbons. Fig. 6d and e demonstrate that the CO2 selectivity of both catalysts decreases with increasing reaction temperatures, a trend that coincides with an increase in hydrocarbon selectivity. Notably, FeCoK/ZrO2 consistently exhibits lower CO2 selectivity than FeCoK across all temperature ranges, suggesting that the active sites of FeCoK are more conducive to CO2 formation. To investigate this further, spent FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts, post-reaction at 360 °C for 12 h, were analyzed using XRD techniques, as shown in Fig. 2Ac and Bc. The XRD pattern for FeCoK reveals diffraction lines of Fe5C2 (PDF 01–076–3842) and Fe3O4 (PDF 01–071–6336), whereas only the Fe5C2 phase is observable for FeCoK/ZrO2. Given that the Fe3O4 phase is reported to be an active site for the water-gas shift reaction [33,34], the higher CO2 selectivity in FeCoK can likely be attributed to the presence of Fe3O4 species. The STY of C2 C4 olefins over FeCoK follows a volcanic trend, starting at 4.2 mmol gcat −1 at 300 °C, peaking at 13.1 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 340 °C, and then decreasing to 9.9 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 380 °C, as shown in Fig. 6f. Conversely, the STY of C2 C4 olefins over FeCoK/ZrO2 steadily increases with rising reaction temperatures, reaching a maximum of 13.2 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 380 °C (Fig. 6f). Fig. 6g indicates that the ratio of C2 C4 olefins to paraffins is higher for FeCoK than for FeCoK/ZrO2, implying that a greater selectivity of FeCoK for light olefin formation. Consequently, despite the higher overall STY of hydrocarbons for FeCoK/ZrO2 at temperatures between 340 and 360 °C, the STY of C2 C4 olefins remains lower compared to FeCoK. This lower C2 C4 olefin-to-paraffin ratio in FeCoK/ZrO2 could be attributed to its significantly higher H2 adsorption (Table 1), which likely facilitates enhanced hydrogen spillover, promoting the hydrogenation of olefins into paraffins. The higher STY of C2 C4 olefins observed with the FeCoK/ZrO2 catalyst at 380 °C can be ascribed to its enhanced activity in converting CO to hydrocarbons which is evidenced by the high hydrocarbon STY of 36.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 380 °C. Figs. 6h and 6i display the hydrocarbon distribution over FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts, respectively. For FeCoK, methane (CH4) content starts at 34.8 % at 300 °C, dips to 27.7 % at 320 °C, and climbs to 51.2 % at 380 °C. In contrast, FeCoK/ZrO2 shows higher methane contents at 300–360 °C but a lower content of 45.2 % at 380 °C. The content of C2 C4 olefins in FeCoK shows a consistent decline from 54.3 % to 33.1 % between 300 °C and 380 °C. Conversely, FeCoK/ZrO2 starts with a lower 46.8 % at 300 °C, with a slight increase from 34.3 % to 34.8 % between 360 °C and 380 °C. The C5+ fraction in FeCoK exhibits an increase from 300 °C to 320 °C, followed by a decline towards 380 °C, suggesting a shift towards the production of lighter hydrocarbons at higher temperatures. In contrast, the C5+ output for FeCoK/ZrO2 remains fairly consistent between 320 °C and 380 °C, demonstrating a reduced sensitivity to temperature in the formation of heavier hydrocarbons. This trend may be attributed to the higher proportion of medium basicity sites on FeCoK/ZrO2, as indicated in Table 2, which potentially stabilizes the adsorption of intermediates, thus favoring the synthesis of longer-chain hydrocarbons. Characterization of spent FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 The catalyst structure of FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2, post-testing at 360 °C for 12 h, was analyzed using TEM, as depicted in Fig. 7 a and b. These figures reveal large Fe5C2 particles enveloped by carbon layers. Similar large Fe5C2 particles are observed in FeCoK/ZrO2 (Fig. 7c and d), indicating that dispersed Fe particles tend to agglomerate, forming larger particles during the reaction. Carbon layers are seen covering both the Fe5C2 particles and clusters of ZrO2 nanoparticles. Additionally, ZrO2 nanoparticles are deposited on the external surfaces of the Fe5C2 particles, potentially altering the electronic properties of Fe5C2 as well as its catalytic performance. The XPS spectra (Fig. 8 ) for Fe 2p in FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2, analyzed using the parameters outlined by Grosvenor et al. [35], indicate Fe3+ in both catalysts. Post-reaction, FeCoK-S and FeCoK/ZrO2-S show broadened Fe 2p spectra, likely due to carbon layer accumulation on Fe5C2 particles, as XPS analyzes up to 10 nm depth [36]. Co 2p XPS spectra, fitted according to Biesinger et al. [37], reveal a more pronounced satellite peak in FeCoK/ZrO2, suggesting a change in cobalt's electronic environment, possibly indicating Co-O-Zr bond formation [32]. Both spent catalysts exhibit broad Co 2p spectra, likely from carbon coverage. The Zr 3d spectrum in FeCoK/ZrO2 shows peaks corresponding to Zr-O (181.9 and 184.2 eV) and, post-reaction, Zr-C bonds (179.4 and 181.7 eV) [38–40]. C 1s spectra in spent catalysts reveal a sharper CC bond, with FeCoK/ZrO2 displaying an additional Fe-C peak, not found in FeCoK, implying thicker carbon layers in the latter. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 flow was conducted on spent FeCoK and FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts to assess carbon species formed after a 12 h reaction at 360 °C. Fig. 9 a and b show the TGA patterns and the associated derivative weight loss curves for both catalysts, revealing three separate phases of weight reduction: moisture desorption at 35–100 °C, iron carbide decomposition at 300–500 °C, and amorphous carbon decomposition above 500 °C. FeCoK demonstrates weight losses of 11.8 % (iron carbide) and 16.5 % (amorphous carbon), whereas FeCoK/ZrO2 shows lower losses at 8.0 % and 10.0 %, respectively. When normalized per gram of Fe content, these values become 25.7 %/gFe and 35.9 %/gFe for FeCoK and 50.0 %/gFe and 62.5 %/gFe for FeCoK/ZrO2, indicating FeCoK/ZrO2's higher activity. Table 3 summarizes their metal compositions, best STY for C2 C4 olefins, and carbon formation amount. Conclusions The primary goal of this study is to elucidate the function of ZrO2 in iron-cobalt-potassium (FeCoK) based catalysts for the conversion of syngas into light olefins. Our characterization results demonstrate that incorporating ZrO2 support enhances the dispersion of iron (Fe), cobalt (Co), and potassium (K) species. This enhancement contributes to improved reducibility of Fe2O3 and Co3O4, as well as KNO3, and leads to an increase in both medium and strong hydrogen adsorption, along with an elevation in medium basicity levels. Notably, the STY of hydrocarbons at 300 and 320 °C over FeCoK/ZrO2 catalysts was lower compared to FeCoK. This observation can be attributed to the augmented medium basicity in FeCoK/ZrO2, which results in excessively strong adsorption of intermediates, subsequently reducing hydrocarbon production. Additionally, the heightened levels of medium and strong hydrogen adsorption in FeCoK/ZrO2 contribute to a decrease in the ratio of C2 C4 olefins to paraffins. However, at elevated temperatures of 360 and 380 °C, the STY of hydrocarbons over FeCoK/ZrO2 surpasses that of FeCoK. This improvement is likely due to the increased reaction temperature mitigating the effects of strong intermediate adsorption. Furthermore, the quantity of carbons normalized per mass of iron, derived from iron carbide and amorphous carbon on FeCoK/ZrO2, is greater than that on FeCoK. This indicates more extensive active sites in the FeCoK/ZrO2 catalyst. Our findings provide fundamental insights into the role of ZrO2 in enhancing the performance of FeCoK catalysts for syngas conversion to light olefins, paving the way for the rational design of more efficient catalysts in this domain. coredata.dc:description: The primary aim of this study is to understand the role of ZrO2 in iron-cobalt-potassium (FeCoK) based catalysts for converting syngas to light olefins. Our findings reveal that ZrO2 support notably enhances the dispersion of Fe, Co, and K species, thus improving the reducibility of Fe2O3, Co3O4, and KNO3. This leads to increased medium and strong hydrogen adsorption and elevated medium basicity. At lower temperatures (300 °C and 320 °C), the space-time yield (STY) of hydrocarbons over FeCoK/ZrO2 is less than FeCoK due to the strong adsorption of intermediates by the increased basicity. However, at higher temperatures (360 °C and 380 °C), this trend reverses, indicating the high-temperature mitigates strong adsorption effects. The FeCoK/ZrO2 catalyst achieved the best STY of C2 C4 olefins of 13.2 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 380 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Role of ZrO2 in enhancing FeCoK catalysts for syngas conversion to light olefins
